author: @theoutstander
text: You have to apply alpha manually in opencv. Essentially taking a weighted average of the existing image and the object that you are drawing on it.

author: @BluEagl
text: A method of 'brightening' at overlaps I once used: 1. Opencv uses numpy arrays 2. Numpy arrays can be directly added to each other, or values in the array can be incremented 3. For each unit covering a pixel, increment the pixel value or add a prebuilt numpy array there 4. Each unit added to the pixel will increase the byte value (1..2..255, etc) making it 'brighter'.  If you want to use the alpha concept, check out opencv's addWeighted() here: https://docs.opencv.org/3.0-beta/doc/py_tutorials/py_core/py_image_arithmetics/py_image_arithmetics.html  and here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36921496/how-to-join-png-with-alpha-transparency-in-a-frame-in-realtime#37198079

author: @Xohoo370
text: Regarding the positioning of buildings I don't think it would be wise to point them allways towards the center.  First you limit the possible places and potentially block your paths.  Second some expansions are orientated differently, so you could end up building all buildings in the mineral line. There are also exceptions, sometimes you want to build shieldbatteries and cannons inside the mineral line. Anyways, really enjoing this series :)

author: @archiatrus1093
text: Just a thought: all the units types already have IDs. Why not use them as "grey value"? Of course you need to scale it to 0..255 for human visualization but the network shouldn't care too much? Furthermore, I would then use a two channel image. First channel for your units, second channel for enemy units. That helps with mirror matchups if my idea above us used. And even if not I assume that it maybe helps with learning?!  And questions: why do you use 8 times the radius? I guess you don't use filled circles because of the alpha problem?  Anyway great tutorials. It's time I let go of my c++ bot and finally try Python-sc2 :D
